Title: the hesitation ramification

Amy: This is nice, that we all get to eat together.
Hmm. Can we maybe put the phones down and have an actualhuman conversation?
Just think of the first 245 as the prequel.
Well, that makes sense. The prefrontal cortex is responsible for planning and anticipation, and patients with brain lesions on their…
Sheldon, you scared me. That wasn’t funny.

Okay, the notion that you can read a few books and come up with a definitive theory of comedy is absurd. I mean, humour is a complex neurological… (Sheldon drops his trousers) Okay, that’s pretty good.
I don’t think I want to go out with you anymore.
Sheldon, how many words are you gonna go through?
He’s home trying to use science to determine the basis of humour.
It’s exhausting. Do you have any idea how hard it is to laugh at a knock-knock joke that starts with knock-knock-knock, Amy, knock-knock-knock, Amy, knock-knock-knock, Amy?
Leonard: Uh, no reason. I just think it’s sexier when things are left to the imagination.
Is it true even when the man lets his dog lick peanut butter off his tongue?
I take it back. That was funny.
I bet that bit killed at The Chuckle Hut.
You know, I think we’re zeroing in on your problem.
Are you set on people laughing with you? ‘Cause if you’re cool with at you…
I know, but you’re going to be a TV star and you haven’t left me yet. That takes guts.
You still got the part. That’s a huge accomplishment.
Honey, you only had, like, three lines. That wasn’t gonna happen anyway.
Oh, come on, no, that’s not what I meant.
I don’t, look, you know, words don’t always have to mean things.
Nope. Uh, uh, I might not know what I meant, but I know that I didn’t mean that. Not this guy. Oh, no way.
I don’t know, I got all confused when you said honestly.

Look, do I think that you are talented and that you are beautiful? Of course I do. But isn’t Los Angeles full of actresses who are just as talented, just as beautiful? All right, look, we’ll come back to that.

That is not what I said. Look, I think you’re really good. I truly do. But this is an incredibly hard thing that you’re shooting for. I mean, the odds of anyone becoming a successful actor are like a million to one.
That was really crappy of me. What you’re trying to do is hard, but people do make it, and I really do believe you could be one of them.
And to show you how much I believe in you, I kind of got you an audition.
There’s this thing online, you put yourself on tape and just send it in, anyone can do it.
So? Even if it is, you have a huge advantage because you’re an actual actress. Most of the people doing this are just weirdoes and nerds. Wolowitz sent his in two days ago.

Look, maybe it is a long shot, but sometimes long shots happen. Luke Skywalker was only given one chance to destroy the Death Star. He had to get a torpedo into an exhaust port that was only two meters wide, but with the help of The Force, he… wow, I can feel you hating me right now.
Well, I don’t think you called it idiotic.
Okay, listen to me, this is just a minor setback.
Look, you know I love you but, but you’re, you’re drunk and sad and feeling lost.
That is not what I said.
Penny proposed, and I didn’t say yes.
Because I’m afraid to know the answer.
That’s it? You’re not gonna make some dumb joke or some inappropriate comment?
Did you just put a kick me sign on my back?
Sheldon: We can, but thanks to Steve Jobs, we don’t have to.
Yay, Penny.
Why is that funny? That’s just unhygienic.

I don’t think so. I believe that a joke is a brief oral narrative with a climactic humorous twist. For example, uh, Wolowitz’s mother is so fat that she decided to go on a diet, or exercise, or both. See? The twist is that people don’t usually change. Well, they don’t.

Wait, if Howard’s mother is coming, then you should also steal marbles. Because she’s obese, and hippos are obese, and in the popular board game Hungry Hungry Hippos, they eat marbles. Maybe I need to dumb these down for you.
Leonard, do you think I’m funny?
I think I’m hysterical.
The philosopher Henri Bergson says it’s funny when a human being behaves like an object.
Oh, he didn’t perform stand-up comedy, he was a philosopher.
Perhaps I’ll spend some time developing a unified theory of comedy, which will allow me to elicit laughter from anyone at any time. Unless they’re German, ’cause that’s a tough crowd.
I don’t get it.
I don’t know about you, but I’m very uncomfortable with all this.
I’ve never seen this show before and now I’m starting with episode 246? It’s unnatural.
All right.
Well, don’t ask me. Until I see the prequel, I’m lost.
I’ve been studying how to make people laugh. They say that comedy is tragedy plus time. Let’s tickle some ribs.
This is interesting. Apparently, a key component in some forms of humour is the element of surprise.
BRAIN LESIONS!
Or maybe you have a stick up your prefrontal cortex.
Excellent.
Kumquat?
Ointment?
Now, would you say ointment is more, equal to, or less funny than kumquat?
Will you please stop joking around? I’m trying to figure this out.
All of them.
Who’s in the mood to laugh?
But I used science to construct the perfect joke.
So, a sandwich, a rabbi and yo mama walk into a bar. Where are you going?
Should I follow you?
Leonard, wait.
I forgot to tell you the sandwich is promiscuous.
Can’t sleep?
Would you like to talk about it?
Why not?
Does that mean the relationship is over?
Why don’t you ask her?
Well, I’m sorry.
No. You’re my friend, and, I’m sorry.
No. That wouldn’t be funny at all.
Penny: Guys, guys, you’re never gonna believe this.
I just got a part on a TV show.
Um, NC… II… or, you know, NCSTD… I don’t know, it’s, it’s, you know, it’s the one with the letters and I’m gonna be on it!
Yeah.
Um, I play a customer in a diner and I flirt with Mark Harmon.
Well, yeah. Why?
Hey, guys, don’t forget, my episode’s on TV tomorrow night.
Oh, that’s so sweet of you, but I was gonna steal food from here. You know, my treat.
We haven’t even gotten to my scene yet.
Okay, shh, guys, guys, this is it.
Are you kidding me?
Well, the diner scene. Where’s my diner scene?
No, there was supposed to be a big scene with me and Mark Harmon, but it’s gone.
They must’ve cut it.
This doesn’t make any sense. I mean, I, I thought I did a, a really good job, I… Excuse me.

Ugh, this is such a disaster. My parents had all my relatives over. They got one of those six-foot sandwiches, and got my brother a day pass out of rehab and now he’s missing and the sandwich is missing, and they’re probably in Mexico by now. So humiliating.
Yeah, but this was supposed to be my break, okay? People were gonna see me in this show and it was gonna lead to bigger things. More auditions, more parts. Now none of that’s gonna happen.
Unbelievable.
Then what did you mean?
I think you meant that you don’t believe in me.
I want you, right now, to give me your 100% honest opinion.
Do you think I have what it takes to really make it as an actress?
So you think I’ll be on TV and in movies and win awards.
Yes, honestly.
How could you say that?
Oh.
No, please. Don’t stop, go on. Tell me how I’m gonna be a waitress for the rest of my life.
Wow, thank you.
You didn’t get your part cut.
And you didn’t get your part cut. Yep, bunch of old guys rocking out in a band, all with erectile dysfunction, you didn’t get your part cut!
We can, but the part of Penny might get cut.
Thank you.
Are you serious? For what?
What? How did you manage that?
Come on Leonard, this is just a PR stunt.
Really, let it go.
Hey.
Look, I know you were just trying to help with your Star Wars thing. I didn’t mean to call it idiotic.
Oh. Sorry, I meant to. Anyway, um, I was just upset with myself. I wasn’t mad at you. I just feel like everything is falling apart.

No, it’s not okay. Look at me, okay? I took a temp job as a waitress forever ago, and I’m still doing it. I can’t quit, because guess what? I can’t do anything else. And I finally get my big break, and it goes away. I’m such a mess.
Really? ‘Cause this morning at Starbucks, a pair of old underwear fell out of my pant leg. And it wasn’t the only one in there.
No, it’s not, okay? I’ve been out here for, like, ten years. I’ve nothing to show for it.
You’re right. I do have you. Mm. Let’s get married.
Ooh. Leonard Hofstadter, will you marry me?
Did you seriously just say um?
Okay, so, so you don’t want to marry me?
No, forget it. I take it back. Offer’s off the table.
I’m gonna go.
No, no, I just need to be alone.
Howard: If you’re really desperate to meet women and like having food eaten out of your mouth, I could set you up with my mom.
Really? I never for a second thought it’d be anything else.
If you’re so intimidated by talking to attractive girls, maybe you should practice by talking to regular people.
I’m serious. Go to the mall, talk to anybody, practice, that way when you eventually do talk to a cute girl, it won’t be so scary.
Fake a laugh? Do you ever do that with me?
Well, I’d be able to tell anyway.
Please, I’ve made plenty of girls laugh, sometimes just by asking them out. (Bernadette laughs uncontrollably) Yeah? Well, I fake my orgasms.
Star Wars audition, take one, starring Howard Joel Wolowitz, real-life astronaut. Vader is here, now, on this moon. I felt his presence. He’s come for me. He can feel when I’m near…
I’m in the middle of something.
Raj: Ooh, Mark Harmon, he’s a dreamboat.
So I read a study that says a man with a dog is three times more likely to get a woman’s phone number.

I almost met someone last night, but I blew it. I was walking Cinnamon and this girl introduced herself, but she was so cute I panicked and said, wouldn’t it be easier if instead of talking we could just sniff each other’s butts?
You mean like fatties and uggos?
No. No pretty girls. The point is to talk to regular people and work our way up to pretty girls.
That depends. On any level, do you think she’s hot?
Yeah, she seems friendly and easy to… never mind, she’s gone. You know, maybe talking to people is too hard.
I don’t know. They’re dressed very stylishly. They’re probably stuck-up. This is ridiculous. The next person that walks by, no matter who it is, they’re the one. We’re gonna die here.
Uh, do, do you like being a mall security guard?
Bernadette: Raj, when you said you were gonna bring a date to watch Penny’s thing tonight, I didn’t think you meant Stuart.
Well, Stuart’s cute in his own way.
Or just keep dating the possum.
If you want him to stop, sometimes the easiest thing to do is just fake a laugh.
How many times do I have to tell you to replace the toilet paper when it’s empty?
Stuart: When I was a baby, my mother called me her little possum.
Fine. How about that old lady with the walker?
How about that lady in the sweat suit, speed-walking?
We could go over to that department store, practice on the mannequins.
How about those guys on that bench over there? They look pathetic. I bet we could talk to them.
Voice on television: Parsa doesn’t have those kind of resources.
Second voice: No, and that’s why he had Erin Pace rewire it…
Man on TV: I guess it’s you and me, kid.
Penny (on phone): No, Dad, I don’t think they cut me out of the show because I was too pretty. No, I don’t need you to come out and kick Mark Harmon’s ass. Daddy, I gotta go. I love you. Bye.
Voice on TV: All right, baby, here’s the deal.
Leonard (on phone): Yes, how much for a hundred long-stemmed red roses? Really? How much for three?
